reference_contexts:

Appointments to these posi- tions shall be subject to such noncompeti- tive examination as may be prescribed by OPM.

Schedule C. Positions of a confidential or policy-determining character shall be list- ed in Schedule C.

§6.1 Authority

to except positions

from the competitive service.

(a) OPM may except positions from the competitive service when it deter- mines that (A) appointments thereto through competitive examination are not practicable, or (B) recruitment from among students attending quali- fying educational institutions or indi- viduals who have recently completed qualifying educational programs can better be achieved by devising addi- tional means for recruiting and assess- ing candidates that diverge from the processes generally applicable to the competitive service. These positions shall be listed in OPM’s annual report for the fiscal year in which the excep- tions are made.

Schedule D. Positions other than those of a confidential or policy-determining char- acter for which the competitive service re- quirements make impracticable the ade- quate recruitment of sufficient numbers of students attending qualifying educational institutions or individuals who have re- cently completed qualifying educational programs shall be listed in Schedule D. These positions are temporarily placed in the excepted service to enable more effec- tive recruitment from all segments of soci- ety by using means of recruiting and as- sessing candidates that diverge from the rules generally applicable to the competi- tive service.

Schedule E. Positions of administrative law judge appointed under 5 U.S.C. 3105 shall be listed in Schedule E. Conditions of good ad- ministration warrant placing the position of administrative law judge in the excepted service and exempting appointment to this position from the requirements of 5 CFR, part 302, including examination and rating requirements, though each agency shall follow the principle of veteran preference as far as administratively feasible.

(b) OPM shall decide whether the du- ties of any particular position are such that it may be filled as an excepted po- sition under the appropriate schedule.

This differs from competitive service positions which would typically require competitive examination processes.

user_input: According to federal regulations, what are the performance requirements for Senior Executive Service (SES) performance management systems, and how do they align with agency mission and strategic planning initiatives?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

System standards means the OPM-es- tablished requirements for perform- ance management systems.

(2) Align performance requirements with agency mission and strategic planning initiatives;

§430.304 SES performance manage-

ment systems.

(a) To encourage excellence in senior executive performance, each agency must develop and administer one or more performance management sys- tems for its senior executives in ac- cordance with the system standards es- tablished in §430.305.

(b) Performance management sys-

tems must provide for—

(1) Identifying executives covered by

the system;

(2) Monitoring progress in accom- plishing critical elements and perform- ance requirements and conducting progress reviews at least once during the appraisal period, including inform- ing executives on how well they are performing;

(3) Establishing an official perform- ance appraisal period for which an an- nual summary rating must be pre- pared;

(4) Establishing a minimum appraisal

period of at least 90 days;

(5) Ending the appraisal period at any time after the minimum appraisal pe- riod is completed, but only if the agen- cy determines there is an adequate basis on which to appraise and rate the senior executive’s performance and the shortened appraisal period promotes ef- fectiveness; and

(3) Define performance standards for each of the summary rating perform- ance levels, which also may be used for the individual elements or performance requirements being appraised;

(4) Appraise each senior executive’s performance at least annually against performance requirements based on es- tablished performance standards and other measures;

(5) Derive an annual summary rating through a mathematical method that ensures executives’ performance aligns with level descriptors contained in per- formance standards that clearly dif- ferentiate levels above fully successful, while prohibiting a forced distribution of rating levels for senior executives;

(6) Establish five summary perform-

ance levels as follows:

(i) An outstanding level; (ii) An exceeds fully successful level; (iii) A fully successful level; (iv) A minimally satisfactory level;

and

(v) An unsatisfactory level; (7) Include equivalency statements in the system description for agency-spe- cific terms for the five summary per- formance levels aligning them with the five performance levels required in §430.305(a)(6); and

(8) Use performance appraisals as a basis to adjust pay, reward, retain, and develop senior executives or make other personnel decisions, including re- movals as specified in §430.312.

(6) Establishing criteria and proce- dures to address performance of senior executives who are on detail, tempo- rarily reassigned, or transferred as de- scribed at §430.312(c)(1), and for other special circumstances established by the agency.

(b) An agency may develop its own performance management system for senior executives in accordance with the requirements of this section.

(c) OPM may establish, and refine as needed, a basic performance manage- ment system incorporating all require- ments of this section, which agencies may adopt, with limited adaptation,

performance.

(a) Each senior executive must have a performance plan that describes the individual and organizational expecta- tions for the appraisal period that clearly fall within the senior execu- tive’s area of responsibility and con- trol.']
reference: According to the context, SES performance management systems must align performance requirements with agency mission and strategic planning initiatives as specified in the system standards. These systems must provide for identifying executives covered by the system, monitoring progress in accomplishing critical elements and performance requirements, conducting progress reviews at least once during the appraisal period, and informing executives on how well they are performing. The systems must establish an official performance appraisal period with an annual summary rating, with a minimum appraisal period of at least 90 days. They must define performance standards for each summary rating level, appraise each senior executive's performance annually against these requirements, and derive an annual summary rating through a mathematical method that ensures alignment with level descriptors while prohibiting forced distribution of ratings. The systems must establish five summary performance levels: outstanding, exceeds fully successful, fully successful, minimally satisfactory, and unsatisfactory. Additionally, they must include equivalency statements for agency-specific terms and use performance appraisals as a basis for personnel decisions including pay adjustments, rewards, retention, development, and removals. Each senior executive must have a performance plan describing individual and organizational expectations that fall within their area of responsibility and control.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides comprehensive details about SES performance management system requirements, including the need to align performance with agency mission, establishing performance levels, conducting regular reviews, creating performance plans, and using appraisals for personnel decisions, with only minor details about specific strategic planning implementation potentially missing.
relevancy_score_reasoning:
This question is exceptionally valuable for multiple stakeholders in the federal employment ecosystem. For HR specialists and agency leadership, it directly addresses the critical performance management framework for Senior Executive Service (SES) members, which is a key component of high-level federal workforce governance. The question demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of how performance management is strategically linked to agency mission and planning.

The question's strengths include:
1. High Relevance: It specifically targets SES performance regulations under Title 5, which governs federal employee management
2. Strategic Depth: By connecting performance requirements to mission and strategic planning, it goes beyond basic procedural inquiry
3. Broad Applicability: Useful for HR professionals, current and aspiring SES members, agency leaders, and those studying federal management practices
4. Practical Significance: Performance management for senior executives is crucial for organizational effectiveness and accountability

The comprehensive nature of the question suggests an advanced information need that would require nuanced understanding of federal performance management principles, making it particularly valuable for professionals seeking in-depth knowledge of federal employment regulations.

user_input: How is the alternate method applied when promoting an employee to a GS-9 position that involves a change in occupational series?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

Example of alternate method: A GS–7, step 7, employee in Atlanta is promoted to a GS–9 position in Wash- ington, DC. The promotion involves not only a change in grade but also a change in the employee’s occupational series. In Washington, DC, no special rate schedule would apply to a GS–7 or GS–9 position in the old occupational series, but a special rate schedule does apply to the GS–9 position in the new occupational series. Thus, different pay schedules apply before and after pro- motion, and the alternate method would result in a higher rate than the standard method. As provided in para- graph (d)(2)(ii) of this section, the agency must apply the alternate meth- od and compare the result to the result derived under the standard method, as follows:

Step A Apply the geographic conversion rule in §531.205 to determine the rates of basic pay for the GS–7, step 7, position in Washington, DC. Based on the GS–7 position before promotion (including the old occupational series), the pay schedules applica- ble to the employee in Washington, DC, would be the General Schedule and the locality rate sched- ule applicable in Washington, DC.

Step B Using the underlying General Schedule, increase the GS–7, step 7, rate by two within-grade in- creases, which produces the GS–7, step 9, rate.

Step C The payable (highest) rate of basic pay for GS–7, step 9, is the corresponding GS–7, step 9, locality rate in Washington, DC.

415

VerDate Sep<11>2014 14:38 May 14, 2025 Jkt 265008 PO 00000 Frm 00425 Fmt 8010 Sfmt 8010 Y:\SGML\265008.XXX 265008

R F C h t i

w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o

s d r a w d e m

§531.215

5 CFR Ch. I (1–1–25 Edition)

Step D

If the employee were promoted to a GS–9 position in the old occupational series, the highest appli- cable rate range for that GS–9 position after pro- motion would be the GS–9 locality rate range in Washington, DC. The GS–9, step 3, locality rate is the lowest step rate in that range that equals or exceeds the GS–7, step 9, locality rate from step C.

Step E Convert the GS–9, step 3, locality rate to the higher GS–9, step 3, special rate that applies to the em- ployee’s position after promotion (including the new occupational series). That GS–9, step 3, special rate is the payable rate of basic pay upon promotion.']
reference: When promoting an employee to a GS-9 position that involves a change in occupational series, the alternate method is applied through a specific process. First, the geographic conversion rule is applied to determine basic pay rates for the pre-promotion position in the new location. Next, the GS-7, step 7 rate is increased by two within-grade increases to produce the GS-7, step 9 rate. The payable rate becomes the corresponding GS-7, step 9 locality rate in the new location. Then, if the employee were promoted in the old occupational series, the GS-9, step 3 locality rate would be identified as the lowest step rate that equals or exceeds the GS-7, step 9 locality rate. Finally, this GS-9, step 3 locality rate is converted to the higher GS-9, step 3 special rate that applies to the employee's position after promotion in the new occupational series. This special rate becomes the payable rate of basic pay upon promotion. The agency must apply this alternate method when it results in a higher rate than the standard method, as specified in paragraph (d)(2)(ii) of the relevant section.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides a detailed, step-by-step explanation of exactly how the alternate method is applied when promoting an employee to a GS-9 position with a change in occupational series, including specific steps A through E that outline the precise process of calculating the new pay rate.
relevancy_score_reasoning:
This question is highly relevant and practical for federal HR specialists, managers involved in personnel actions, and employees seeking promotion. It addresses a specific technical aspect of federal personnel management under Title 5, focusing on promotion procedures and pay-setting methodologies when an employee changes occupational series. The question demonstrates a nuanced understanding of federal employment regulations, particularly around pay administration and career progression.

The query is particularly useful because:
1. It deals with a complex personnel action involving series change and promotion
2. Requires detailed knowledge of Title 5 pay-setting rules
3. Has direct implications for both employees and HR professionals
4. Suggests a real-world scenario of career development within federal service

The specificity of mentioning a GS-9 position and the change in occupational series indicates a sophisticated information need that goes beyond basic procedural questions. HR specialists would find this extremely valuable for ensuring correct pay calculations and compliance with federal personnel regulations. Managers would benefit from understanding the precise mechanisms of promoting and compensating employees during series transitions.

The only reason it does not receive a perfect 5 rating is that it represents a somewhat specialized scenario that might not be universally applicable to all federal employees. However, for those directly involved in personnel management, this is a highly informative and practical question.

user_input: What happens when a Recent Graduate program participant gets caught in a reduction in force situation and how they get terminated from the program if they don't finish it good, and what options they got for conversion to permanent job if they done good?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

§362.306 Reduction in force and termi-

nation.

(1) Successfully completed at least 1- year of continuous service in addition to all the requirements of the Recent Graduates Program;

(2) Demonstrated successful job per- formance consistent with the applica- ble performance appraisal program es- tablished under the agency’s approved performance appraisal system that re- sults in a rating of record (or summary rating) of at least Fully Successful or equivalent and a recommendation for conversion by the first-level super- visor; and

(a) Reduction in force. Recent Grad- uates are in excepted service Tenure Group II for purposes of §351.502 of this chapter. Expiration of the Recent Graduates appointment is not other- wise subject to part 351 of this chapter. (b) Terminations. (1) Except as pro- vided in paragraph (b)(2) of this sec- tion, as a condition of employment, a Recent Graduate appointment expires at the end of the agency prescribed Program period, plus any agency-ap- proved extension, unless the Partici- pant is selected for noncompetitive conversion under §362.306.

(3) Met the OPM Qualification Stand- ard for the competitive service position to which the Recent Graduate will be converted.

(b) An agency must make the non- competitive conversion effective on the date the service requirement is met, or at the end of an agency-approved ex- tension, if applicable.

(c) A Recent Graduate may be con- verted to a permanent or term position at a different agency when the fol- lowing conditions are met:

(2) A Recent Graduate who held a ca- reer-conditional or career appointment in an agency immediately before enter- ing the Program, and fails to complete the Program for reasons that are not related to misconduct, poor perform- ance, or suitability, may, at the agen- cy’s discretion, be placed in a perma- nent competitive service position, as appropriate, in the employing agency.

(1) The employing (or losing) agency is unable to convert the Recent Grad-

334

VerDate Sep<11>2014 14:38 May 14, 2025 Jkt 265008 PO 00000 Frm 00344 Fmt 8010 Sfmt 8010 Y:\SGML\265008.XXX 265008

R F C h t i

w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o

s d r a w d e m

Office of Personnel Management

§362.403

']
reference:
According to the context, Recent Graduates are classified in excepted service Tenure Group II for reduction in force purposes under §351.502. The expiration of a Recent Graduate appointment is not otherwise subject to part 351 of this chapter.

Regarding termination, a Recent Graduate appointment expires at the end of the agency prescribed Program period, plus any agency-approved extension, unless the Participant is selected for noncompetitive conversion. However, if a Recent Graduate held a career-conditional or career appointment immediately before entering the Program and fails to complete the Program for reasons not related to misconduct, poor performance, or suitability, they may, at the agency's discretion, be placed in a permanent competitive service position in the employing agency.

For conversion to a permanent position, a Recent Graduate must have successfully completed at least 1-year of continuous service, demonstrated successful job performance with a rating of at least Fully Successful or equivalent, received a recommendation for conversion from their first-level supervisor, and met the OPM Qualification Standard for the competitive service position. The agency must make the noncompetitive conversion effective on the date the service requirement is met or at the end of an approved extension. A Recent Graduate may also be converted to a permanent or term position at a different agency under certain conditions, including if the employing agency is unable to convert the Recent Graduate.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides substantial information about reduction in force, termination conditions, and conversion options for Recent Graduate program participants, covering most aspects of the question with details about tenure group, performance requirements, and potential conversion pathways, though some specific nuances about termination procedures might be slightly unclear.
relevancy_score_reasoning:
This question, despite its somewhat informal language, addresses a substantive and practical concern for federal employees in the Recent Graduate Program. It touches on several important aspects of federal employment regulations under Title 5, including:

1. Program participation requirements
2. Reduction in force (RIF) procedures
3. Career progression options for program participants
4. Job security and conversion opportunities

The question demonstrates a genuine need for information about the protections, rights, and potential career paths for participants in federal government entry-level programs. While the grammar is informal, the underlying information need is clear and highly relevant to federal employment policies.

The query would be particularly useful for:
- Recent Graduate Program participants
- HR specialists managing program transitions
- Managers overseeing entry-level talent

user_input: what is a regular schedule vs first 40-hour tour of duty
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

WORK SCHEDULES

(b) When it is impracticable to pre- scribe a regular schedule of definite hours of duty for each workday of a scheduled administrative regularly workweek, the head of an agency may establish the first 40 hours of duty per- formed within a period of not more than 6 days of the administrative workweek as the basic workweek. A first 40-hour tour of duty is the basic workweek without the requirement for specific days and hours within the ad- ministrative workweek. All work per- formed by an employee within the first 40 hours is considered regularly sched- uled work for premium pay and hours of duty purposes. Any additional hours of officially ordered or approved work within the administrative workweek are overtime work.

§610.121 Establishment of work sched-

ules.']

This first 40-hour tour doesn't require specific days and hours within the administrative workweek, but can be performed within a period of not more than 6 days. All work performed by an employee within these first 40 hours is considered regularly scheduled work for premium pay and hours of duty purposes, while any additional officially ordered or approved work within the administrative workweek counts as overtime.

user_input: what PRB do when they look at performance-based pay adjustment and who cant be part of it?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

Details and job changes.

(a) When a senior executive is de- tailed or temporarily reassigned for 120 days or longer, the gaining organiza- tion must set performance goals and requirements for the detail or tem- porary assignment. The gaining organi- zation must appraise the senior execu- tive’s performance in writing, includ- ing through the use of automated sys- tems, and this appraisal must be con- sidered when deriving the initial sum- mary rating.

(b) When a senior executive is reas- signed or transferred to another agency after completing the minimum ap- praisal period, the supervisor must ap- praise the executive’s performance in writing, including through the use of automated systems, before the execu- tive leaves and provide this informa- tion to the executive.

(c) The most recent annual summary rating and any subsequent appraisals must be transferred to the gaining agency or organization. The gaining supervisor must consider the rating and appraisals when deriving the ini- tial summary rating at the end of the appraisal period.

(b) Functions. (1) Each PRB must con- sider agency performance as commu- nicated by the oversight official through the performance appraisal guidelines when reviewing and evalu- ating the initial summary rating, any senior executive’s response, and any higher-level official’s findings and rec- ommendations on the initial summary rating or the results of an alternative review. The PRB may conduct any fur- ther review needed to make its rec- ommendations. The PRB may not re- view an initial summary rating to which the executive has not been given the opportunity to respond in writing, including through the use of auto- mated systems.

(2) The PRB must make a written recommendation, including through the use of automated systems, to the appointing authority about each senior executive’s annual summary rating, performance-based pay adjustment, and performance award.

(3) PRB members may not take part in any PRB deliberations involving their own appraisals, performance- based pay adjustments, and perform- ance awards.

§430.311 Performance Review Boards

§430.312 ']
reference: The Performance Review Board (PRB) must make a written recommendation to the appointing authority about each senior executive's performance-based pay adjustment, along with their annual summary rating and performance award. These recommendations can be made through automated systems. Importantly, PRB members are not allowed to participate in any PRB deliberations that involve their own performance-based pay adjustments, appraisals, or performance awards.

user_input: What are the legal implications of using the National Archives and Records Administration's official seal without permission according to federal regulations?
reference_contexts:
["<1-hop>

page_content='R F C h t i

w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o

s d r a w d e m

 Title 5 Administrative Personnel

Parts 1 to 699

Revised as of January 1, 2025

Containing a codification of documents of general applicability and future effect

As of January 1, 2025

Published by the Office of the Federal Register National Archives and Records Administration as a Special Edition of the Federal Register

VerDate Sep<11>2014 14:38 May 14, 2025 Jkt 265008 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 8091 Sfmt 8091 Y:\SGML\265008.XXX 265008

R F C h t i

w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o

s d r a w d e m

U.S. GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL EDITION NOTICE

 Legal Status and Use of Seals and Logos

The seal of the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) authenticates the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) as the official codification of Federal regulations established under the Federal Register Act. Under the provisions of 44 U.S.C. 1507, the contents of the CFR, a special edition of the Federal Register, shall be judicially noticed. The CFR is prima facie evidence of the origi- nal documents published in the Federal Register (44 U.S.C. 1510).

It is prohibited to use NARA’s official seal and the stylized Code of Federal Regulations logo on any republication of this material without the express, written permission of the Archivist of the United States or the Archivist’s designee. Any person using NARA’s official seals and logos in a manner inconsistent with the provisions of 36 CFR part 1200 is subject to the penalties specified in 18 U.S.C. 506, 701, and 1017.

"]
reference: According to the information in Title 5 Administrative Personnel, using the National Archives and Records Administration's (NARA) official seal without permission has specific legal implications. The document states that "It is prohibited to use NARA's official seal and the stylized Code of Federal Regulations logo on any republication of this material without the express, written permission of the Archivist of the United States or the Archivist's designee." Furthermore, it specifies that "Any person using NARA's official seals and logos in a manner inconsistent with the provisions of 36 CFR part 1200 is subject to the penalties specified in 18 U.S.C. 506, 701, and 1017." This indicates that unauthorized use of these official symbols can result in legal penalties under specific U.S. Code provisions.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides specific details about the legal consequences of using NARA's official seal without permission, stating that unauthorized use is subject to penalties under 18 U.S.C. 506, 701, and 1017, which directly addresses the legal implications of unauthorized seal usage.

Subject to receipt of satisfactory evi- dence of the qualifications of the per- son to be appointed, OPM may author- ize an appointment in the competitive service without competitive examina- tion whenever it finds that the duties or compensation of the position are such, or that qualified persons are so rare, that, in the interest of good civil- service administration, the position cannot be filled through open competi- tive examination. Any person here- tofore or hereafter appointed under this section shall acquire a competitive status upon completion of at least one year of satisfactory service and compli- ance with such requirements as OPM may prescribe. [28 FR 10024, Sept. 14, 1963]

§4.2 Prohibition against racial, polit- ical or religious discrimination.

No person employed in the executive branch of the Federal Government who has authority to take or recommend any personnel action with respect to any person who is an employee in the competitive service or any eligible or applicant for a position in the competi- tive service shall make any inquiry concerning the race, political affili- ation, or religious beliefs of any such employee, eligible, or applicant. All disclosures concerning such matters shall be ignored, except as to such

All such decisions and information con- cerning variations noted in the official record shall be published promptly in a Federal Personnel Manual Letter or Bulletin and in the Director’s next an- nual report.

§5.1 Civil Service regulations.']
reference: Federal regulation §4.2 protects federal employees and applicants from racial, political or religious discrimination through several specific provisions. The regulation explicitly prohibits any person employed in the executive branch who has authority over personnel actions from making inquiries concerning race, political affiliation, or religious beliefs of employees, eligibles, or applicants in the competitive service. It further mandates that all disclosures concerning such matters shall be ignored, with the only exception being membership in political parties or organizations that legally disqualify someone from government employment. Additionally, the regulation strictly prohibits any discrimination being exercised, threatened, or promised against or in favor of any employee, eligible, or applicant for a position in the competitive service based on race, political affiliation, or religious beliefs, except as authorized or required by law. For enforcement of these protections, Part 5 establishes that the Director may secure effective implementation of civil service laws, rules, and regulations through investigation and evaluations as outlined in §5.2. The enforcement mechanisms include the Director's authority to investigate and evaluate compliance with civil service laws and Executive orders that impose responsibilities on the Office of Personnel Management.

reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

When an appointee of the Senior Executive Service moves to another position in the Service, either with the same or a different agency, all appro- priate performance-related documents five years old or less shall be forwarded in the Employee Performance File along with the individual’s OPF.

(3) When an employee in the Senior Executive Service accepts a Presi- dential appointment pursuant to 5 U.S.C. 3392(c), the employee’s perform- ance file shall be retained as long as the employee remains employed under that Presidential appointment. When the appointment ends, and the indi- vidual does not return to the Senior Executive Service, the employee’s per- formance file shall be destroyed in ac- cordance with agency procedures.

(c) Where any performance-related document is needed in connection with an ongoing administrative, negotiated, quasi-judicial, or judicial proceeding, and it continues to be retained in this system rather than another system, it may be retained for as long as nec- essary beyond the retention schedules identified in paragraphs (a) and (b) of this section.

(3) Appraisals of unacceptable per- formance, where a notice of proposed demotion or removal is issued but not effected, and all documents related thereto, manual and automated, pursu- ant to 5 U.S.C. 4303(d) must be de- stroyed after the employee completes one year of acceptable performance from the date of the written advance notice of the proposed removal or re- duction in grade notice. Under condi- tions specified by an agency, and ear- lier destruction date is permitted and destruction must be no later than 30 days after the year is up.

(b) Performance records for Senior Executive Service appointees, includ- ing those serving under a Presidential appointment under 5 U.S.C. 3392(c), are to be retained as follows:

reference: When a non-SES employee's Official Personnel Folder (OPF) is sent to another servicing office in the employing agency, to another agency, or to the National Personnel Records Center, the "losing" servicing office must include all performance ratings of record that are 4 years old or less in the OPF. This includes the performance plan on which the most recent rating was based, and the summary rating prepared when the employee changes positions, as prescribed in part 430. Additionally, the "losing" office will purge from the OPF all performance ratings and performance plans that are more than 4 years old, along with other performance-related records, according to agency policy established under §293.404(a)(2) and in accordance with the Guide to Personnel Recordkeeping.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides detailed information about performance rating retention requirements when a non-SES employee's Official Personnel File (OPF) is transferred, specifically stating that performance ratings of record 4 years old or less, including the performance plan and summary rating, should be included in the transferred OPF, while ratings older than 4 years should be purged.
relevancy_score_reasoning: Despite the informal spelling, this question addresses a substantive and practical records management issue directly relevant to Title 5 regulations. Performance ratings are critical documentation in federal employee personnel files, and understanding retention requirements during inter-agency transfers is important for HR professionals, managers, and employees themselves. The question demonstrates a genuine need to understand record-keeping protocols that impact employee performance documentation and potential future career opportunities. While the spelling could be improved, the underlying information need is clear and highly applicable to federal employment practices. The question would help ensure proper handling of official personnel records during agency transfers, which is crucial for maintaining accurate employee performance histories.

reference: According to the context, written documentation for retention incentives must include several elements as outlined in §575.308. Additionally, a signed written service agreement becomes mandatory in specific circumstances. The regulations state that "an authorized agency official must require a signed written service agreement for any employee who may receive a higher retention incentive as a result of approval of a waiver of the maximum limit on the amount of a retention incentive under paragraph (e)(1) of this section." The service agreement itself must include details about the length of the service period determined by an authorized agency official. The agreement must also specify the conditions under which the agency must terminate the service agreement before the employee completes the agreed-upon service period, such as if an employee is demoted, separated for cause, receives a rating of record less than "Fully Successful" or equivalent, or otherwise fails to fulfill the terms of the agreement. Furthermore, the service agreement must outline the effect of termination, including conditions under which the agency will pay additional retention incentive payments for partially completed service. However, it's worth noting that a written service agreement is not required under certain conditions described in paragraph (f) of section §575.310.

reference: According to §630.306, annual leave restored under 5 U.S.C. 6304(d) that was forfeited because of administrative error must be scheduled and used not later than the end of the leave year ending 2 years after the date of restoration of the annual leave. This time limit applies specifically to cases of administrative error as mentioned in §630.306(a)(1). Regarding accumulation limits, the regulations specify different earning rates based on years of service: employees with less than 3 years of service earn 1 hour of annual leave for each 20 hours in pay status; employees with 3 but less than 15 years of service earn 1 hour of annual leave for each 13 hours in pay status; and employees with 15 years or more of service earn 1 hour of annual leave for each 10 hours in pay status. The regulations also address accumulation limits, noting that employees may carry forward different amounts of unused annual leave depending on their accumulated balance: the full amount if it's between 30-45 days, or up to 45 days (or more if entitled under section 6304(c) of title 5) if the accumulated balance exceeds 45 days.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides detailed information about the time limit for restored annual leave (must be used by the end of the leave year ending 2 years after restoration) and includes specific annual leave earning rates for employees with different years of service (1 hour per 20, 13, or 10 hours in pay status), which directly addresses most aspects of the question.

For HR specialists, this question is crucial for understanding how to handle leave forfeiture and potential remedies. The technical nature of the question suggests a genuine need for precise regulatory interpretation, which goes beyond surface-level policy understanding. It requires a deep dive into specific CFR provisions related to leave administration, making it valuable for anyone seeking comprehensive knowledge of federal employment regulations.

The multi-layered approach—examining both the time limit for reclaiming forfeited leave and connecting it to service-based accumulation limits—demonstrates a sophisticated approach to understanding federal employment policies.

user_input: What are the requirments for SES performence managment systems acording to OPM, and how do they aline with agnecy mission and stratigic planning initatives for senior executivs?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

System standards means the OPM-es- tablished requirements for perform- ance management systems.

(2) Align performance requirements with agency mission and strategic planning initiatives;

§430.304 SES performance manage-

ment systems.

(a) To encourage excellence in senior executive performance, each agency must develop and administer one or more performance management sys- tems for its senior executives in ac- cordance with the system standards es- tablished in §430.305.

(b) Performance management sys-

tems must provide for—

(1) Identifying executives covered by

the system;

(2) Monitoring progress in accom- plishing critical elements and perform- ance requirements and conducting progress reviews at least once during the appraisal period, including inform- ing executives on how well they are performing;

(3) Establishing an official perform- ance appraisal period for which an an- nual summary rating must be pre- pared;

(4) Establishing a minimum appraisal

period of at least 90 days;

(5) Ending the appraisal period at any time after the minimum appraisal pe- riod is completed, but only if the agen- cy determines there is an adequate basis on which to appraise and rate the senior executive’s performance and the shortened appraisal period promotes ef- fectiveness; and

(3) Define performance standards for each of the summary rating perform- ance levels, which also may be used for the individual elements or performance requirements being appraised;

(4) Appraise each senior executive’s performance at least annually against performance requirements based on es- tablished performance standards and other measures;

(5) Derive an annual summary rating through a mathematical method that ensures executives’ performance aligns with level descriptors contained in per- formance standards that clearly dif- ferentiate levels above fully successful, while prohibiting a forced distribution of rating levels for senior executives;

(6) Establish five summary perform-

ance levels as follows:

(i) An outstanding level; (ii) An exceeds fully successful level; (iii) A fully successful level; (iv) A minimally satisfactory level;

and

(v) An unsatisfactory level; (7) Include equivalency statements in the system description for agency-spe- cific terms for the five summary per- formance levels aligning them with the five performance levels required in §430.305(a)(6); and

(8) Use performance appraisals as a basis to adjust pay, reward, retain, and develop senior executives or make other personnel decisions, including re- movals as specified in §430.312.

(6) Establishing criteria and proce- dures to address performance of senior executives who are on detail, tempo- rarily reassigned, or transferred as de- scribed at §430.312(c)(1), and for other special circumstances established by the agency.

(b) An agency may develop its own performance management system for senior executives in accordance with the requirements of this section.

(c) OPM may establish, and refine as needed, a basic performance manage- ment system incorporating all require- ments of this section, which agencies may adopt, with limited adaptation,

performance.

(a) Each senior executive must have a performance plan that describes the individual and organizational expecta- tions for the appraisal period that clearly fall within the senior execu- tive’s area of responsibility and con- trol.']
reference:
According to OPM requirements, SES performance management systems must be developed and administered by each agency to encourage excellence in senior executive performance, in accordance with system standards established in §430.305. These systems must align performance requirements with agency mission and strategic planning initiatives.

The systems have several specific requirements, including: identifying executives covered by the system; monitoring progress in accomplishing critical elements and performance requirements with at least one progress review during the appraisal period; establishing an official performance appraisal period for annual summary ratings; establishing a minimum appraisal period of at least 90 days; defining performance standards for each summary rating level; appraising each senior executive's performance annually; and deriving an annual summary rating through a mathematical method.

Additionally, the systems must establish five summary performance levels: outstanding, exceeds fully successful, fully successful, minimally satisfactory, and unsatisfactory. The systems must include equivalency statements for agency-specific terms aligning with these five required performance levels. Performance appraisals must be used as a basis for personnel decisions including pay adjustments, rewards, retention, development, and removals. The systems must also establish criteria for executives on detail, temporarily reassigned, or transferred.

Each senior executive must have a performance plan describing individual and organizational expectations that fall within their area of responsibility and control.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides comprehensive details about SES performance management system requirements, including performance levels, appraisal periods, monitoring progress, and alignment with agency missions, with only minor details about specific strategic planning initiatives potentially missing.
relevancy_score_reasoning:
Despite some spelling errors, this question demonstrates a sophisticated and substantive inquiry into Senior Executive Service (SES) performance management systems, which is directly relevant to Title 5 regulations. The question addresses critical aspects of federal executive performance management, including:

1. Regulatory compliance with Office of Personnel Management (OPM) standards
2. Alignment of performance systems with agency strategic objectives
3. Performance management for senior executives

The question is particularly valuable for:
- HR specialists responsible for designing and implementing performance management frameworks
- Senior executives seeking to understand performance evaluation criteria
- Agency leaders interested in strategic alignment of executive performance
- Researchers studying federal executive management practices

While the spelling and grammar could be improved, the underlying information need is clear and represents a meaningful exploration of federal employment policy. The question goes beyond surface-level inquiry by connecting performance management to broader strategic planning initiatives, which indicates a nuanced understanding of executive performance evaluation.

The practical implications of understanding SES performance management systems are significant, as they directly impact executive accountability, agency effectiveness, and strategic goal achievement. Therefore, this question receives a high rating for its relevance, depth, and potential utility across federal employment stakeholders.

user_input: what is the calendar year limitation for administrative leave for full-time employees vs part-time employees vs employees with uncommon tour of duty?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

(2) As a reward to recognize the per- formance or contributions of an em- ployee or group of employees (i.e., in lieu of a cash award or a time-off award).

§630.1404 Calendar year limitation.

(a) General. Under 5 U.S.C. 6329a(b), during any calendar year, an agency may place an employee on administra- tive leave for no more than 10 work- days. In this context, the term ‘‘place’’ refers to a management-initiated ac- tion to put an employee in administra- tive leave status, with or without the employee’s consent, for the purpose of conducting an investigation (as defined in §630.1502). The 10-workday annual limit does not apply to administrative leave for other purposes. After an em- ployee has been placed on administra- tive leave in connection with such an investigation for 10 workdays, the agency may place the employee on in- vestigative leave under subpart O of this part, if necessary (see 5 U.S.C. 6329b(b)(3)(A) and §630.1504(a)(1)). This calendar year limitation applies sepa- rately to each agency that may employ an employee during the year. Use by different agencies is not aggregated.

(6) In developing agency policies re- garding the appropriate uses and cor- responding amounts of administrative leave and in approving specific inci- dents of administrative leave where the particular use was not specifically au- thorized in agency policies, authorized agency officials must consider the fol- lowing factors:

(b) Conversion to a limitation on hours. This 10-workday calendar year limita- tion is converted to an aggregate limit on hours, taking into account the dif- ferent workdays that can apply to em- ployees under different work schedules, as follows:

(i) The regulations in this subpart; (ii) The effect on productivity and the agency’s ability to meet mission needs;

(iii) Current Administration policies that identify Governmentwide inter- ests;

(1) For a full-time employee (includ- ing an employee on a regular 40-hour basic workweek or a flexible or com- pressed work schedule under 5 U.S.C. chapter 61, subchapter II, but excluding an employee on an uncommon tour of duty), the calendar year limitation is 80 hours;

(iv) The strength of the justification for using appropriated funds for the ad- ministrative leave in question;

(2) For a full-time employee with an uncommon tour of duty under §630.210, the calendar year limitation is equal to

903

VerDate Sep<11>2014 14:38 May 14, 2025 Jkt 265008 PO 00000 Frm 00913 Fmt 8010 Sfmt 8010 Y:\SGML\265008.XXX 265008

R F C h t i

w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o

s d r a w d e m

§630.1405

5 CFR Ch. I (1–1–25 Edition)

the number of hours in the biweekly uncommon tour of duty (or the average biweekly hours for uncommon tours for which the biweekly hours vary over an established cycle);

(3) For a part-time employee, the cal- endar year limit is prorated based on the number of hours in the officially scheduled part-time tour of duty estab- lished for purposes of charging leave when absent (e.g., for a part-time em- ployee who has an officially scheduled half-time tour of 40 hours in a biweekly pay period, the calendar year limita- tion is 40 hours, which is half of the 80- hour limitation for full-time employ- ees);

(4) For an employee who has more than one type of work schedule in ef- fect during different parts of a calendar year, the calendar year limit on hours of administrative leave must be applied by—

(b) Employees may be granted ad- ministrative leave only for hours with- in the tour of duty established for pur- poses of charging annual and sick leave when absent. For full-time employees, that tour is the 40-hour basic work- week as defined in 5 CFR 610.102, the basic work requirement established for employees on a flexible or compressed work schedule as defined in 5 U.S.C. 6121(3), or an uncommon tour of duty under §630.210.', '<2-hop>

Calendar year limitation.']
reference: According to the context, the calendar year limitation for administrative leave varies by employee type. For full-time employees on a regular 40-hour basic workweek or a flexible/compressed work schedule, the limitation is 80 hours per calendar year. For full-time employees with an uncommon tour of duty, the limitation equals the number of hours in their biweekly uncommon tour (or the average biweekly hours for variable uncommon tours over an established cycle). For part-time employees, the limit is prorated based on their officially scheduled part-time tour established for leave charging purposes - for example, a half-time employee with a 40-hour biweekly schedule would have a 40-hour annual limit (half of the 80-hour full-time limitation). For employees with multiple work schedule types during different parts of a calendar year, the limit must be applied accordingly. This 10-workday limitation applies separately to each agency employing the person during the year and is not aggregated across different agencies.
groundedness_score_reasoning: The context provides precise and detailed information about administrative leave calendar year limitations for different types of employees, including full-time employees with standard and uncommon tours of duty, as well as part-time employees, making it possible to fully and unambiguously answer the question.
relevancy_score_reasoning:
This is an excellent, highly practical question that directly addresses a specific administrative policy within Title 5 CFR regulations. The question demonstrates a nuanced understanding of potential variations in administrative leave calculations based on different employment classifications (full-time, part-time, and uncommon tour of duty). 

The usefulness of this question is high for several key stakeholders:
1. HR Specialists: They need precise guidance on how to calculate and track administrative leave across different employee types
2. Managers: Understanding leave limitations helps in workforce planning and managing employee time off
3. Federal Employees: Knowing their specific administrative leave entitlements is crucial for understanding their workplace rights and benefits
4. Payroll and Compliance Teams: Accurate interpretation of leave regulations is essential for proper record-keeping and regulatory compliance

These systems hold senior executives accountable within their assigned areas of responsibility and control for both individual and organizational performance by: encouraging excellence in senior executive performance; aligning executive performance plans with results-oriented goals required by GPRAMA or other strategic planning initiatives; setting and communicating individual and organizational goals within the executive's area of responsibility; reporting on meeting organizational goals; systematically appraising senior executive performance using balanced measures; and using performance appraisals as a basis for pay, awards, development, retention, removal, and other personnel decisions.

reference_contexts:

(b) The Associate Director for Retire- ment and Insurance and his or her dele- gates are designated by the Director and authorized to perform all the du- ties for which the Director is respon- sible under the Debt Collection Act of 1982 and Office of Personnel Manage- ment regulations on debts caused by payments from the Civil Service Re- tirement and Disability Fund (sub- chapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84), claims under the provisions of the Fed- eral Employees’ Life Insurance Fund (chapter 87), the Retired Federal Em- ployees Health Benefits Act (74 Stat. 849), the Employees Health Benefits Fund (chapter 89), the Panama Canal Construction Annuity Act (58 Stat.

Subpart B—Salary Offset

SOURCE: 59 FR 35216, July 11, 1994, unless

otherwise noted.

§179.201 Purpose.

The purpose of the Debt Collection Act of 1982 (Pub. L. 97–365), is to pro- vide a comprehensive statutory ap- proach to the collection of debts due the Federal Government. These regula- tions implement section 5 of the Act which authorizes the collection of debts owed by Federal employees to the Federal Government by means of salary offset, except that no claim may be collected by such means if out- standing for more than 10 years after the agency’s right to collect the debt first accrued, unless facts material to the Government’s right to collect were not known, and could not reasonably have been known, by the official or of- ficials who were charged with the re- sponsibility for discovery and collec- tion of such debts. These regulations are consistent with the regulations on salary offset published by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) on July 3, 1984 (49 FR 27470) in 5 CFR part 550, subpart K.

§179.202 Scope.

(a) These regulations provide proce- dures for the collection of monies from a Federal employee’s pay by salary off- set to satisfy certain debts owed the Government.

(b) These regulations apply to all col- lections by the Director of OPM (ex- cept collections involving debts be- cause of payments made from the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, payments made under the Re- tired Federal Employees Health Bene- fits Act (74 Stat. 849), the Panama Canal Construction Annuity Act and the Lighthouse Service Widows’ Annu- ity Act and payments or premiums re- lating to the Federal Employees’ Life Insurance Fund or the Federal Employ- ees Health Benefits Fund) from:

(1) Federal employees who owe debts

to OPM; and

(c) These regulations do not apply to debts or claims arising under the Inter- nal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended (26 U.S.C. 1 et seq.); the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 301 et seq.); the tariff laws of the United States; or to any case where collection of a debt by sal- ary offset is explicitly provided for or prohibited by another statute (e.g., travel advances in 5 U.S.C. 5705 and em- ployee training expenses in 5 U.S.C. 4108).

(d) Section 179.207 does not apply to any adjustment to pay arising from an employee’s election of coverage or a change in coverage under a Federal benefits program requiring periodic de- ductions from pay, if the amount to be recovered was accumulated over four pay periods or less.

(e) Nothing in these regulations pre- cludes the compromise, suspension, or termination of collection actions, where appropriate, under the standards implementing the Federal Claims Col- lection Act (31 U.S.C. 3711 et seq., 4 CFR parts 101–105, 38 CFR 1.900 et seq.).']

According to the context, salary offset applies to collections by the Director of OPM, but specifically excludes collections involving debts from payments made from several federal benefits programs including the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, payments under the Retired Federal Employees Health Benefits Act, the Panama Canal Construction Annuity Act, the Lighthouse Service Widows' Annuity Act, and payments or premiums related to the Federal Employees' Life Insurance Fund or Federal Employees Health Benefits Fund. Additionally, section 179.207 doesn't apply to adjustments to pay from an employee's election of coverage or change in coverage under a Federal benefits program requiring periodic deductions, if the amount was accumulated over four pay periods or less. The regulations also don't apply to debts arising under specific laws like the Internal Revenue Code, Social Security Act, tariff laws, or cases where collection by salary offset is explicitly provided for or prohibited by another statute.

reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

VerDate Sep<11>2014 14:38 May 14, 2025 Jkt 265008 PO 00000 Frm 00278 Fmt 8010 Sfmt 8010 Y:\SGML\265008.XXX 265008

R F C h t i

w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o

s d r a w d e m

Office of Personnel Management

§351.302

Transfer of function means the trans- fer of the performance of a continuing function from one competitive area and its addition to one or more other competitive areas, except when the function involved is virtually identical to functions already being performed in the other competitive area(s) affected; or the movement of the competitive area in which the function is performed to another commuting area.

Undue interruption means a degree of interruption that would prevent the completion of required work by the em- ployee 90 days after the employee has been placed in a different position under this part. The 90-day standard should be considered within the allow- able limits of time and quality, taking into account the pressures of priorities, deadlines, and other demands. How- ever, a work program would generally not be unduly interrupted even if an employee needed more than 90 days after the reduction in force to perform the optimum quality or quantity of work. The 90-day standard may be ex- tended if placement is made under this part to a low priority program or to a vacant position.

[51 FR 319, Jan. 3, 1986, as amended at 58 FR 65533, Dec. 15, 1993; 60 FR 3062, Jan. 13, 1995; 62 FR 62500, Nov. 24, 1997; 73 FR 29388, May 21, 2008]

§351.204 Responsibility of agency.

Subpart C—Transfer of Function

SOURCE: 52 FR 10024, Mar. 30, 1987, unless

otherwise noted.

§351.301 Applicability.

(a) This subpart is applicable when the work of one or more employees is moved from one competitive area to another as a transfer of function re- gardless of whether or not the move- ment is made under authority of a statute, Executive order, reorganiza- tion plan, or other authority.

(b) In a transfer of function, the func- tion must cease in the losing competi- tive area and continue in an identical form in the gaining competitive area (i.e., in the gaining competitive area, the function continues to be carried out by competing employees rather than by noncompeting employees).

[52 FR 10024, Mar. 30, 1987, as amended at 60 FR 3062, Jan. 13, 1995]

§351.302 Transfer of employees.

(a) Before a reduction in force is made in connection with the transfer of any or all of the functions of a com- petitive area to another continuing competitive area, each competing em- ployee in a position identified with the transferring function or functions shall be transferred to the continuing com- petitive area without any change in the tenure of his or her employment.

Each agency covered by this part is responsible for following and applying the regulations in this part when the agency determines that a reduction force is necessary.

§351.205 Authority of OPM.

The Office of Personnel Management may establish further guidance and in- structions for the planning, prepara- tion, conduct, and review of reductions in force. OPM may examine an agen- cy’s preparations for reduction in force at any stage. When OPM finds that an agency’s preparations are contrary to the express provisions or to the spirit and intent of these regulations or that they would result in violation of em- ployee rights or equities, OPM may re- quire appropriate corrective action.

[51 FR 319, Jan. 3, 1986, as amended at 66 FR 66710, Dec. 27, 2001]', '<2-hop>

§359.608 Transfer of function.

']
reference: Transfer of function means the transfer of the performance of a continuing function from one competitive area and its addition to one or more other competitive areas, except when the function involved is virtually identical to functions already being performed in the other competitive area(s) affected; or the movement of the competitive area in which the function is performed to another commuting area. In a transfer of function, the function must cease in the losing competitive area and continue in an identical form in the gaining competitive area (i.e., in the gaining competitive area, the function continues to be carried out by competing employees rather than by noncompeting employees). Before a reduction in force is made in connection with the transfer of any or all of the functions of a competitive area to another continuing competitive area, each competing employee in a position identified with the transferring function or functions shall be transferred to the continuing competitive area without any change in the tenure of their employment.

§531.605 Determining an employee’s

official worksite.

(a)(1) Except as otherwise provided in this section, the official worksite is the location of an employee’s position of record where the employee regularly performs his or her duties.

(d) For an employee covered by a following

telework agreement, the rules apply:

(1) If the employee is scheduled to work at least twice each biweekly pay period on a regular and recurring basis at the regular worksite for the employ- ee’s position of record, the regular worksite (where the employee’s work activities are based) is the employee’s official worksite. However, in the case of such an employee whose work loca- tion varies on a recurring basis, the employee need not work at least twice each biweekly pay period at the reg- ular official worksite (where the em- ployee’s work activities are based) as long as the employee is regularly per- forming work within the locality pay area for that worksite.

(2) If the employee’s work involves recurring travel or the employee’s work location varies on a recurring basis, the official worksite is the loca- tion where the work activities of the employee’s position of record are based, as determined by the employing agency, subject to the requirement that the official worksite must be in a locality pay area in which the em- ployee regularly performs work.

(3) An agency must document an em- ployee’s official worksite on an em- ployee’s Notification of Personnel Ac- tion (Standard Form 50 or equivalent). (b) For an employee who is relocated and authorized to receive relocation expenses under 5 U.S.C. chapter 57, sub- chapter II (or similar authority), the official worksite is the established worksite for the position in the area to which the employee has been relocated. For an employee authorized to receive relocation expenses under 5 U.S.C. 5737 in connection with an extended assign- ment resulting in a temporary change of station, the worksite associated with the extended assignment is the of- ficial worksite. (a) An agency may establish tem- porary transitional Schedule C posi- tions necessary to assist a department or agency head during the 1-year period immediately following a change in presidential administration, when a new department or agency head has en- tered on duty, or when a new depart- ment or agency is created. (b) The number of temporary transi- tional Schedule C positions established by an agency cannot exceed either 50 percent of the highest number of per- manent Schedule C positions filled by that agency at any time over the pre- vious 5 years, or three positions, whichever is higher. reference:
When an employee receiving a saved rate has their official worksite changed, the saved rate must be adjusted in conjunction with the change in worksite consistent with the geographic conversion rule for retained rates under 5 CFR 536.303(b). This applies to employees covered by a pay system that provides different basic pay schedules based on geographic location, such as the General Schedule pay system.

As for termination of a saved rate, it must be terminated if the employee has a break in service of 1 workday or more, if the employee is demoted based on unacceptable performance or conduct or at the employee's request, or if the employee becomes entitled to a rate of basic pay that is equal to or higher than the saved rate.

Additionally, for employees receiving a saved rate on May 1, 2005, any locality payment under 5 U.S.C. 5304 formerly paid in addition to the employee's saved rate no longer applied as of that date. Any locality-adjusted saved rate in effect and payable on April 30, 2005, had to be converted to an equal saved rate effective on May 1, 2005.

ment systems.

(a) To encourage excellence in senior executive performance, each agency must develop and administer one or more performance management sys- tems for its senior executives in ac- cordance with the system standards es- tablished in §430.305.

tems must provide for—

period of at least 90 days;

user_input: what worktime mean for FLSA exemption and how it different from workday?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

Workday means the period between the commencement of the principal ac- tivities that an employee is engaged to perform on a given day and the ces- sation of the principal activities for that day. The term is further explained in §551.411.

Worktime, for the purpose of deter- mining FLSA exemption status, means time spent actually performing work. This excludes periods of time during which an employee performs no work, such as standby time, sleep time, meal periods, and paid leave.

Worktime in a representative workweek means the average worktime over a pe- riod long enough to even out normal fluctuations in workloads and is rep- resentative of the job as a whole.

Workweek means a fixed and recur- ring period of 168 hours—seven con- secutive 24-hour periods. It need not

w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o

s d r a w d e m

Office of Personnel Management

§551.202

coincide with the calendar week but may begin on any day and at any hour of a day. For employees subject to part 610 of this chapter, the workweek must be the same as the administrative workweek defined in §610.102 of this chapter.

(d) An employee who clearly meets the criteria for exemption must be des- ignated FLSA exempt. If there is a rea- sonable doubt as to whether an em- ployee meets the criteria for exemp- tion, the employee will be designated FLSA nonexempt.

Workweek basis means the unit of time used as the basis for applying overtime standards under the Act and, for employees under flexible or com- pressed work schedules, under 5 U.S.C. 6121(6) or (7). The Act takes a single workweek as its standard (except for employees engaged in fire protection or law enforcement activities under sec- tion 7(k) of the Act) and does not per- mit the averaging of hours over two or more weeks, except for employees en- gaged in fire protection or law enforce- ment activities under section 7(k) of the Act.

Subpart B—Exemptions and Exclusions

SOURCE: 72 FR 52765, Sept. 17, 2007, unless

otherwise noted.

(e) While established position de- scriptions and titles may assist in making initial FLSA exemption deter- minations, the designation of an em- ployee as FLSA exempt or nonexempt must ultimately rest on the duties ac- tually performed by the employee.

(f) Although separate criteria are provided for the exemption of execu- tive, administrative, and professional employees, those categories are not mutually exclusive. Employees who perform a combination of exempt du- ties set forth in this regulation may also qualify for exemption. For exam- ple, an employee whose primary duty involves a combination of exempt ad- ministrative and exempt executive work may qualify for exemption, i.e., work that is exempt under one section of this part will not defeat the exemp- tion under any other section.

§551.201 Agency authority.

The employing agency must review and make a determination on each em- ployee’s exemption status.

§551.202 General principles.

In all exemption determinations, the agency must observe the following principles:

(a) Each employee is presumed to be FLSA nonexempt unless the employing agency correctly determines that the employee clearly meets the require- ments of one or more of the exemptions of this subpart and such supplemental interpretations or instructions issued by OPM. The agency must designate an employee FLSA exempt when the agen- cy correctly determines that the em- ployee meets the requirements of one or more of the exemptions of this sub- part and such supplemental interpreta- tions or instructions issued by OPM.

(b) Exemption criteria must be nar- rowly construed to apply only to those employees who are clearly within the terms and spirit of the exemption.

(c) The burden of proof rests with the']
reference: According to the context, worktime for the purpose of determining FLSA exemption status means time spent actually performing work. This excludes periods of time during which an employee performs no work, such as standby time, sleep time, meal periods, and paid leave. This differs from workday, which means the period between the commencement of the principal activities that an employee is engaged to perform on a given day and the cessation of the principal activities for that day. The workday concept is further explained in §551.411, while worktime specifically relates to determining FLSA exemption status.

reference: The Federal Wage System operates with local wage survey committees established before each full-scale wage survey. According to the regulations, committee recommendations are developed by majority vote, though any member may submit a minority report to the lead agency. In areas that don't qualify for a local wage survey committee, the lead agency establishes an appropriate local wage survey organization. The Office of Personnel Management has several responsibilities including defining wage area boundaries, prescribing required industries to be surveyed, establishing job coverage requirements, designating lead agencies, and creating a nationwide schedule of wage surveys. Lead agencies are responsible for planning and conducting wage surveys, developing survey specifications, ordering wage surveys, establishing wage schedules, and referring matters to the agency wage committee when needed. Local wage survey committees plan and conduct wage surveys in designated wage areas. Before each full-scale survey, the local wage survey committee must hold a public hearing to receive recommendations from interested parties regarding the area, industries, establishments, and jobs to be covered in the wage survey.

user_input: how PRB members decide on performance-based pay adjustment and what they cant do when it their own pay adjustment?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

Details and job changes.

(a) When a senior executive is de- tailed or temporarily reassigned for 120 days or longer, the gaining organiza- tion must set performance goals and requirements for the detail or tem- porary assignment. The gaining organi- zation must appraise the senior execu- tive’s performance in writing, includ- ing through the use of automated sys- tems, and this appraisal must be con- sidered when deriving the initial sum- mary rating.

(b) When a senior executive is reas- signed or transferred to another agency after completing the minimum ap- praisal period, the supervisor must ap- praise the executive’s performance in writing, including through the use of automated systems, before the execu- tive leaves and provide this informa- tion to the executive.

(c) The most recent annual summary rating and any subsequent appraisals must be transferred to the gaining agency or organization. The gaining supervisor must consider the rating and appraisals when deriving the ini- tial summary rating at the end of the appraisal period.

(b) Functions. (1) Each PRB must con- sider agency performance as commu- nicated by the oversight official through the performance appraisal guidelines when reviewing and evalu- ating the initial summary rating, any senior executive’s response, and any higher-level official’s findings and rec- ommendations on the initial summary rating or the results of an alternative review. The PRB may conduct any fur- ther review needed to make its rec- ommendations. The PRB may not re- view an initial summary rating to which the executive has not been given the opportunity to respond in writing, including through the use of auto- mated systems.

(2) The PRB must make a written recommendation, including through the use of automated systems, to the appointing authority about each senior executive’s annual summary rating, performance-based pay adjustment, and performance award.

(3) PRB members may not take part in any PRB deliberations involving their own appraisals, performance- based pay adjustments, and perform- ance awards.

§430.311 Performance Review Boards

§430.312 ']
reference: According to the context, the Performance Review Board (PRB) makes written recommendations to the appointing authority about each senior executive's performance-based pay adjustment. The PRB considers agency performance as communicated by the oversight official through performance appraisal guidelines when reviewing and evaluating various inputs including the initial summary rating, any senior executive's response, and any higher-level official's findings and recommendations. However, PRB members are explicitly prohibited from taking part in any PRB deliberations involving their own performance-based pay adjustments. This restriction ensures that board members cannot influence decisions about their own compensation.

reference:
The performance award for senior executives is decided through a structured process involving Performance Review Boards (PRBs). The PRB must make a written recommendation (which can be through automated systems) to the appointing authority about each senior executive's performance award, along with their annual summary rating and performance-based pay adjustment. The appointing authority then assigns the final annual summary rating after considering the PRB's recommendations.

PRB members are specifically prohibited from taking part in any PRB deliberations involving their own performance awards. The regulation clearly states: "PRB members may not take part in any PRB deliberations involving their own appraisals, performance-based pay adjustments, and performance awards."

When a senior executive is detailed or temporarily reassigned for 120 days or longer, the gaining organization must set performance goals and requirements for that assignment. The gaining organization must appraise the senior executive's performance in writing (including through automated systems), and this appraisal must be considered when deriving the initial summary rating.

Similarly, when a senior executive is reassigned or transferred to another agency after completing the minimum appraisal period, the supervisor must appraise the executive's performance in writing before the executive leaves and provide this information to the executive. The most recent annual summary rating and any subsequent appraisals must be transferred to the gaining agency or organization, and the gaining supervisor must consider these when deriving the initial summary rating at the end of the appraisal period.

user_input: Under 5 U.S.C. 5305, how do special rates relate to the highest applicable rate range for General Schedule employees?
reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

General Schedule or GS means the classification and pay system estab- lished under 5 U.S.C. chapter 51 and subchapter III of chapter 53. This term also refers to the pay schedule estab- lished under 5 U.S.C. 5332.

Highest applicable rate range means the rate range applicable to an em- ployee based on a given position of record and official worksite that pro- vides the highest rates of basic pay, ex- cluding any retained rates. For exam- ple, a rate range of special rates under 5 U.S.C. 5305 may exceed an applicable locality rate range under 5 U.S.C. 5304 for General Schedule employees. In certain circumstances, the highest ap- plicable rate range may consist of two types of pay rates from different pay schedules—e.g., a range where special rates are higher in the lower portion of the range and locality rates are higher in the higher portion of the range.

Management action means an action (not for personal cause) by an agency official not initiated or requested by an employee which may adversely affect the employee’s grade or rate of basic pay. However, an employee’s placement in or transfer to a position under a for- mal employee development program es- tablished by an agency for recruitment and employee advancement purposes (e.g., Recent Graduates Program) is considered a management action even though the employee initiates or re- quests such placement or transfer.

Official worksite means the official lo- cation of the employee’s position of record as determined under the rules of the applicable pay system (e.g., 5 CFR 531.605 for General Schedule employ- ees). Official worksite is synonymous with the term ‘‘official duty station’’ as used in 5 U.S.C. 5363(c).

OPM means the Office of Personnel

(2) An individual employed by a De- partment of Defense or Coast Guard nonappropriated fund instrumentality

Management.

Payable rate means the highest rate of basic pay to which an employee is

5 CFR Ch. I (1–1–25 Edition)

entitled based on the employee’s posi- tion of record, official worksite, and step (or relative position in range for a GM employee) or, if applicable, a re- tained rate.

Pay schedule means a set of rate ranges established under a single au- thority—i.e., the General Schedule, a law enforcement officer special base rate schedule (for grades GS–3 through 10) under section 403 of FEPCA; a pre- vailing rate schedule (including a spe- cial schedule or special rate schedule) under 5 U.S.C. chapter 53, subchapter IV; a locality rate schedule under 5 U.S.C. 5304 based on GS rates; a local- ity rate schedule under 5 U.S.C. 5304 based on law enforcement officer spe- cial base rates (for grades GS–3 through 10); or a special rate schedule under 5 U.S.C. 5305 or similar author- ity. A pay schedule applies to or covers a defined category of employees based on established coverage conditions (e.g., official worksite, occupation). A pay schedule is considered to apply to or cover an employee who meets the es- tablished coverage conditions even when a rate under that schedule is not currently payable to the employee be- cause of a higher pay entitlement under another pay schedule.']

reference:
To register for career-conditional employment conversion when your name was on a register, you must meet several conditions under §315.703. You qualify if: (1) your name was included on an appropriate certificate while serving in the position, or reconstruction of the register verifies you would have been within reach; (2) the register was being used for career and career-conditional appointments when you were reached; (3) you have been continuously employed since being reached; (4) conversion is initiated before the register expires or during continuous service since being reached; and (5) for non-preference eligibles first reached after February 1955, there were satisfactory reasons for passing over any preference eligibles who preceded you.

After approval of the conversion, you become a career-conditional employee, except in cases where you qualify as a career employee by completing the service requirement for career tenure or are excepted from it by §315.201(c). Upon conversion, you automatically acquire competitive status on completion of probation. Agencies must establish procedures for reviewing disapproved conversions when requested.
